title: Who will be elected governor of Wisconsin in the 2018 election?
preds: Based on the FiveThirtyEight Governor Forecast
My first forecast seems mistaken. This is closer to current polling.

Governor Scot Walker is one of the top Democrat targets to replace as governor in the Midterms. He’s currently seeking a third term as governor of the state having one two previous elections and a recall vote in 2012. Despite Democrats best efforts Walker has continued to survive capturing around 52% of the vote each time. Walker is seen as a very divisive figure in Wisconsin with most people either supporting him or greatly disliking him there appears to be no middle ground. During Walker’s tenure collective bargaining rights of public employee unions were curbed and unions almost completely busted in the state. 
	After surviving a 2012 recall vote in his first term “Dead Man Walker” still manages to elude Democratic efforts to sweep the state of Wisconsin. Walker is hoping the strength of the economy, which is doing very well in Wisconsin will secure his nomination. His opponent, Tony Evers, is the former state superintendent and is running on providing aid to school districts. Evers also champions healthcare and increase in worker wages. Walker’s advantage in this race is that Tony Evers is a bland candidate running primarily on helping the teachers, which while a just cause just doesn’t win over the independent voters who keep Walker in power. Another Walker advantage is that Tammy Baldwin the Democratic senator from Wisconsin is also up for reelection and is also just as divisive. If Tammy wins reelection then Walker is finished but if Walker wins it’ll be razor thin for Tammy. For these reasons I believe the people of Wisconsin will reelect Walker. Walker’s toughest Democrat opponent, Mahlon Mitchell, was defeated in the primary and Evers just won’t be able to motivate the Democratic base to turn out for him despite an increase in voter registration this year. The economy’s success will help propel Walker to a third term. Another huge indicator that Walker will win is that the Marquette poll, A Wisconsin private university poll, found that Walker was up by +1. The Marquette poll has always accurately predicted the Wisconsin elections including in 2014 when Walker was down 7 points in the general election. Regardless of who wins the vote will be around 51-49 or 52-48. https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/can-scott-walker-extend-his-winning-streak-in-wisconsin/2018/11/01/08fa359e-dde8-11e8-b732-3c72cbf131f2_story.html?utm_term=.6147e931f7df

https://www.huffingtonpost.com/entry/democrats-bland-scott-walker-troy-evers-governor_us_5bd74093e4b0a8f17efab16c
Based on the FiveThirtyEight Governor Forecast

I used the I Ching oracle (essentially a random selection).
Scott Walker: hexagram 48, line 2 "the bucket leaks"
Tony Evers: hexagram 36, line 4 "penetrating the heart of darkness"
RPC average from 10/28 to gaussian curve.
Based on the FiveThirtyEight Governor Forecast
Based on the FiveThirtyEight Governor Forecast
note to self: +4% to Dem to convert from my model to 538m.
Evers looks way more normal by comparison

The 538 Governors Forecast was released a couple hours ago. Their forecasted chance of winning: Evers 61.8%, Walker 38.2%. https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/2018-midterm-election-forecast/governor/
I've seen Walker come from behind. Twice!

Like a terrible investment banker, I'm going off momentum. Walker is riding the effects of Kavanaugh very well, in fact it looks to be hurting Evers (but if I'm being honest, all the Kavanaugh analysis is just surmise - PHEPH).
He's also tightening the gap in the polls, which may persuade some otherwise pessimistic Republicans to get out to the polls...

Evers is suffering from the Kavanaugh October Surprise backlash. While RCP average shows Evers still hold a slight edge, and the latest poll shows even split between two campaigns, Walker has momentum: he was down double digit in September. 
In past elections, a tie 3 weeks out from election got Walker a win.
model Dem=59, Rep=41 but adjusting 3 for rising trend on Rep.
Walker is behind kkeeping the status quo on gerrymandering in the state.

Americans For Prosperity announced Wednesday that it had spent $1.5 million on an ad buy opposing Democratic gubernatorial nominee Tony Evers (D-Wis.).
The ad says that Evers supports raising taxes and that he has not specified which taxes or by how much.
The buy marks the group's third set of ads since the August 14 primaries, bringing its total spending to $4.6 million. The first, a $1.8 million buy announced August 18, focused on education. The second, a $1.3 million buy announced September 14, focused on transportation taxes.
Evers, Walker, and four other candidates will appear on the November 6 general election ballot.
Evers is ahead in ALL the polls, but Scott is the Incumbent. This could go either way...
Wisconsin is a Democratic leaning state. People are tired of Walker. The Democrats are extremely energized and the undecideds will break heavily for Evers.
I think Walker will be overcome by the BLUE WAVE which will include Wisconsin Trump voters with "buyers remorse".
Leveraging the wisdom of a crowd. https://www.predictit.org/Market/4555/Which-party-will-win-the-2018-Wisconsin-gubernatorial-race
Evers has a small but consistent lead in polling. That lead combined with democratic enthusiasm gives him a definite but not insurmountable advantage over Walker.
Walker-fatigue will allow Evers to have a run. So much politicking wears out. Being against workers and taking healthcare away is not smart.  Bye-bye Scotto, bye-bye!
The memory of what - 3 recall attempts? Will seem like inviting trouble back for another go at the Unions. Advantage Evers.
